info:
In Spanish, the present tense (el presente) is used to express actions that are happening now, habitual actions, general truths, or actions that will happen in the near future. Conjugating verbs in the present tense involves changing the verb endings to match the subject pronoun. Here's a general overview:

Regular Verb Conjugation:
-AR Verbs:

Example: Hablar (to talk)
Yo hablo (I talk)
Tú hablas (You talk)
Él/Ella/Usted habla (He/She/You talk - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras hablamos (We talk)
Vosotros/Vosotras habláis (You all talk - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes hablan (They/You all talk)
-ER Verbs:

Example: Comer (to eat)
Yo como (I eat)
Tú comes (You eat)
Él/Ella/Usted come (He/She/You eat - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras comemos (We eat)
Vosotros/Vosotras coméis (You all eat - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes comen (They/You all eat)
-IR Verbs:

Example: Vivir (to live)
Yo vivo (I live)
Tú vives (You live)
Él/Ella/Usted vive (He/She/You live - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras vivimos (We live)
Vosotros/Vosotras vivís (You all live - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes viven (They/You all live)
Irregular Verbs:
Some verbs in Spanish are irregular and do not follow the regular conjugation patterns. Common irregular verbs in the present tense include ser, estar, ir, tener, and hacer.
Usage:
Habitual Actions:

Uso el transporte público todos los días. (I use public transportation every day.)
Current Actions:

Estudio español en la universidad. (I am studying Spanish at the university.)
General Truths:

El sol sale por el este. (The sun rises in the east.)
Near Future:

Voy al cine esta noche. (I am going to the movies tonight.)
Notes:
Subject pronouns (yo, tú, él, ella, nosotros, vosotros, ellos) are often omitted in Spanish unless necessary for clarification or emphasis.
Pay attention to irregular verb conjugations and stem-changing verbs.
Mastering the present tense is essential for basic communication in Spanish, as it is used to convey a wide range of meanings and situations.
native_group: 2 Phrases de verbes abstraites au présent

In Spanish, the present tense (el presente) is used to express actions that are happening now, habitual actions, general truths, or actions that will happen in the near future. Conjugating verbs in the present tense involves changing the verb endings to match the subject pronoun. Here's a general overview:

Regular Verb Conjugation:
-AR Verbs:

Example: Hablar (to talk)
Yo hablo (I talk)
Tú hablas (You talk)
Él/Ella/Usted habla (He/She/You talk - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras hablamos (We talk)
Vosotros/Vosotras habláis (You all talk - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes hablan (They/You all talk)
-ER Verbs:

Example: Comer (to eat)
Yo como (I eat)
Tú comes (You eat)
Él/Ella/Usted come (He/She/You eat - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras comemos (We eat)
Vosotros/Vosotras coméis (You all eat - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes comen (They/You all eat)
-IR Verbs:

Example: Vivir (to live)
Yo vivo (I live)
Tú vives (You live)
Él/Ella/Usted vive (He/She/You live - formal)
Nosotros/Nosotras vivimos (We live)
Vosotros/Vosotras vivís (You all live - informal, used in some regions)
Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes viven (They/You all live)
Irregular Verbs:
Some verbs in Spanish are irregular and do not follow the regular conjugation patterns. Common irregular verbs in the present tense include ser, estar, ir, tener, and hacer.
Usage:
Habitual Actions:

Uso el transporte público todos los días. (I use public transportation every day.)
Current Actions:

Estudio español en la universidad. (I am studying Spanish at the university.)
General Truths:

El sol sale por el este. (The sun rises in the east.)
Near Future:

Voy al cine esta noche. (I am going to the movies tonight.)
Notes:
Subject pronouns (yo, tú, él, ella, nosotros, vosotros, ellos) are often omitted in Spanish unless necessary for clarification or emphasis.
Pay attention to irregular verb conjugations and stem-changing verbs.
Mastering the present tense is essential for basic communication in Spanish, as it is used to convey a wide range of meanings and situations.
